title: 1581-B
statement: B. Diameter of Graphtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputCQXYM wants to create a connected undirected graph with $$$n$$$ nodes and $$$m$$$ edges, and the diameter of the graph must be strictly less than $$$k-1$$$. Also, CQXYM doesn't want a graph that contains self-loops or multiple edges (i.e. each edge connects two different vertices and between each pair of vertices there is at most one edge).The diameter of a graph is the maximum distance between any two nodes.The distance between two nodes is the minimum number of the edges on the path which endpoints are the two nodes.CQXYM wonders whether it is possible to create such a graph.InputThe input consists of multiple test cases.The first line contains an integer $$$t (1 \\leq t \\leq 10^5)$$$ â€” the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows.Only one line of each test case contains three integers $$$n(1 \\leq n \\leq 10^9)$$$, $$$m$$$, $$$k$$$ $$$(0 \\leq m,k \\leq 10^9)$$$.OutputFor each test case, printYESif it is possible to create the graph, or printNOif it is impossible. You can print each letter in any case (upper or lower).ExampleInput5 1 0 3 4 5 3 4 6 3 5 4 1 2 1 1OutputYES NO YES NO NONoteIn the first test case, the graph's diameter equal to 0.In the second test case, the graph's diameter can only be 2.In the third test case, the graph's diameter can only be 1.

processed.result: Given a number of nodes and edges, determine if it's possible to create a connected graph with the maximum distance between any two nodes being less than a given value.  The graph cannot have loops or duplicate edges.

You are given three integers $n$, $m$, and $k$.  Determine if it is possible to create a connected undirected graph with $n$ nodes and $m$ edges where the diameter of the graph is strictly less than $k-1$.

The diameter of a graph is the largest distance between any two nodes in the graph. The distance between two nodes is the minimum number of edges needed to travel between them.  

The graph cannot have self-loops (an edge connecting a node to itself) or multiple edges between the same two nodes.


Input:

The input consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains an integer $t$ representing the number of test cases. Each test case has one line with three integers $n$, $m$, and $k$.

Output:

For each test case, print "YES" if it is possible to create the graph, or "NO" if it is impossible.
